title.narrative: OUTPUT 3.1: INSTITUTIONAL WASH CAPACITY

description.narrative: Communities and institutions gain and maintain access to improved, gender-sensitive and climate-resilient WASH services in rural and peri-urban areas.

mailing-address.narrative: Boulevard. du 30 Juin No. 87 Building de la Communauté Hellenique Commune de la Gombe B.P. 7248 Kinshasa

sector.narrative: Data, information, and evidence in local/urban governance
Risk informed Programming for resilience (including policy and strategy development)
Sanitation and hygiene - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) including menstrual hygiene management
WASH - Enabling environment (policies/strategies, coordination, regulation, financing, planning-monitoring-review, sector capacity development and professionalization)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Communities and institutions gain and maintain access to improved, gender-sensitive and climate-resilient WASH services in rural and peri-urban areas.
Existence of water, sanitation and hygiene sector budgeting mechanism
Existence of Child sensitive national or local risk management plans addressing risks related to disasters, climate change, conflict, public health emergencies or other crises

[Existence of a government strategic document on norms and standards in menstrual health and hygiene in the DRC] Existence d'un document stratgique gouvernemental sur les normes et standards dans le domaine de la sant et hygine menstruelle en RDC.
Existence of sector regulation and accountability mechanisms for water, sanitation and hygiene
Local governments (incl. municipalities) with functioning coordination mechanisms to strengthen the delivery of child focused services
(alt) Number of government facilities and other public spaces consistently applying IPC protocols developed with UNICEF-support in the reporting year [COVID]
